articles.headline: The Man in Charge of Fixing Fannie and Freddie Knows Them All Too Well
articles.snippet: Before he was a Treasury official, Craig S. Phillips ran Morgan Stanley’s anything-goes mortgage operation.
articles.abstract: Before he was a Treasury official, Craig S. Phillips ran Morgan Stanley’s anything-goes mortgage operation.
articles.lead_paragraph: You may not know much about Craig S. Phillips, special counselor to Steven Mnuchin, the United States Treasury secretary. Because Mr. Phillips was not a political appointee, he did not face congressional scrutiny before he began directing our nation’s housing policy, one of his main tasks.

articles.headline: 63 Hours: From Chemical Attack to Trump’s Strike in Syria
articles.snippet: The steps leading to President Trump’s order to strike a Syrian airfield in response to a chemical weapons attack on civilians.
articles.abstract: The steps leading to President Trump’s order to strike a Syrian airfield in response to a chemical weapons attack on civilians.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH, Fla. — The decision came Thursday afternoon on Air Force One on the way to Florida. President Trump assembled his National Security Council on his plane, some by secure video link, as the generals made the case that President Bashar al-Assad of Syria had to learn there was a price to pay.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: William T. Walters, Famed Sports Bettor, Is Guilty in Insider Trading Case
articles.snippet: Prosecutors said Mr. Walters made more than $40 million from 2008 to 2014 by realizing profits and avoiding losses based on inside information he received about Dean Foods.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors said Mr. Walters made more than $40 million from 2008 to 2014 by realizing profits and avoiding losses based on inside information he received about Dean Foods.
articles.lead_paragraph: Four times, the authorities went after the famed Las Vegas sports gambler William T. Walters, and four times the man known as Billy emerged victorious.
articles.byline: By Colin Moynihan and Liz Moyer

articles.headline: Bill O’Reilly’s Family Values Book Tops Charts, as He Faces Abuse Claims
articles.snippet: The new book, “Old School,’ is billed as a defense of traditional values and includes advice on how men should treat women respectfully. Initial sales are strong.
articles.abstract: The new book, “Old School,’ is billed as a defense of traditional values and includes advice on how men should treat women respectfully. Initial sales are strong.
articles.lead_paragraph: The timing of Bill O’Reilly’s latest best-selling book could hardly be more awkward.

articles.headline: With Strike Aimed at Halting More Gas Attacks, U.S. Tries to Send Syrians Message
articles.snippet: The question for the Pentagon is whether its action will ensure that poisonous gas will no longer be among the many scourges that plague Syria.
articles.abstract: The question for the Pentagon is whether its action will ensure that poisonous gas will no longer be among the many scourges that plague Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The American cruise-missile strike that destroyed at least 20 warplanes in Syria on Friday was devised by American war planners as a one-time operation to deter President Bashar al-Assad from using his secret stockpile of chemicals ever again.

articles.headline: When Solar Panels Became Job Killers
articles.snippet: A policy change in China hurt workers in Ohio, revealing the trade challenges facing President Trump.
articles.abstract: A policy change in China hurt workers in Ohio, revealing the trade challenges facing President Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: WUHAN, China — Russell Abney raised two children on solar power. The 49-year-old Georgia Tech graduate worked for the last decade in Perrysburg, Ohio, a suburb of Toledo, pulling a good salary as an equipment engineer for the largest American solar-panel maker.

articles.headline: Men Bet She Would Fail; Now She Runs a $26 Billion Fund
articles.snippet: Dawn Fitzpatrick manages the billions in family wealth of the investor George Soros. But she takes over at an unsettled moment for global markets.
articles.abstract: Dawn Fitzpatrick manages the billions in family wealth of the investor George Soros. But she takes over at an unsettled moment for global markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: From the moment Dawn Fitzpatrick stepped onto the American Stock Exchange trading floor as a clerk in 1992, she sensed that the odds were against her. Surrounded by men in jackets barking trade orders, she stood out in her pleated skirt and twin sweater set. Traders around her began wagering over how long Ms. Fitzpatrick, then 22, would last.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Kate Kelly

articles.headline: PTA Gift for Someone Else’s Child? A Touchy Subject in California
articles.snippet: An experiment in distributing parents’ contributions equally across a district is one reason Malibu residents want to separate their schools from Santa Monica’s.
articles.abstract: An experiment in distributing parents’ contributions equally across a district is one reason Malibu residents want to separate their schools from Santa Monica’s.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Of all the inequalities between rich and poor public schools, one of the more glaring divides is PTA fund-raising, which in schools with well-heeled parents can generate hundreds of thousands of dollars a year or more.

articles.headline: Boom or Bust: Stark Partisan Divide on How Consumers View Economy
articles.snippet: Sentiment among Democrats and Republicans has swung sharply since November, creating a gap that — regardless of objective data — is wider than ever.
articles.abstract: Sentiment among Democrats and Republicans has swung sharply since November, creating a gap that — regardless of objective data — is wider than ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: Economics has a foundation in hard numbers — employment, inflation, spending — that has largely allowed it to sidestep the competing partisan narratives that have afflicted American politics and culture.

articles.headline: The Emerging Trump Doctrine: Don’t Follow Doctrine
articles.snippet: In a week of foreign policy moves, President Trump dispensed with dogma and demonstrated a highly improvisational and situational approach to the world
articles.abstract: In a week of foreign policy moves, President Trump dispensed with dogma and demonstrated a highly improvisational and situational approach to the world
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As he confronted a series of international challenges from the Middle East to Asia last week, President Trump made certain that nothing was certain about his foreign policy. To the extent that a Trump Doctrine is emerging, it seems to be this: don’t get roped in by doctrine.

articles.headline: U.S. Strike on Syria Brings Fleeting Hope to Those Caught in Brutal Conflict
articles.snippet: President Trump’s decision to respond with military force to a chemical attack on Syrian civilians was met on the ground with a mix of optimism and doubt.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s decision to respond with military force to a chemical attack on Syrian civilians was met on the ground with a mix of optimism and doubt.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Six years of war in Syria have ravaged the life of Ebrahim Abbas, 27.
articles.byline: By Karam Shoumali and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: Egypt Declares State of Emergency, as Attacks Undercut Promise of Security
articles.snippet: Two suicide bombings at churches in Egypt on Palm Sunday called into question President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi’s image as a bulwark against Islamic extremists.
articles.abstract: Two suicide bombings at churches in Egypt on Palm Sunday called into question President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi’s image as a bulwark against Islamic extremists.
articles.lead_paragraph: TANTA, Egypt — Rattling a country already wrestling with a faltering economy and deepening political malaise, two suicide bombings that killed 44 people at Coptic churches in Egypt on Palm Sunday raised the specter of increased sectarian bloodshed led by Islamic State militants.
articles.byline: By Magdy Samaan and Declan Walsh

articles.headline: Canada Tries to Turn Its A.I. Ideas Into Dollars
articles.snippet: Today’s striking advances in artificial intelligence owe a lot to research in Canada over the years. But the country has so far failed to cash in.
articles.abstract: Today’s striking advances in artificial intelligence owe a lot to research in Canada over the years. But the country has so far failed to cash in.
articles.lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Long before Google started working on cars that drive themselves and Amazon was creating home appliances that talk, a handful of researchers in Canada — backed by the Canadian government and universities — were laying the groundwork for today’s boom in artificial intelligence.

articles.headline: Tillerson, on Eve of Russia Trip, Takes Hard Line on Syria
articles.snippet: The secretary of state called Russia “incompetent” for allowing Syria to retain chemical weapons and accused Moscow of trying to meddle in European elections.
articles.abstract: The secretary of state called Russia “incompetent” for allowing Syria to retain chemical weapons and accused Moscow of trying to meddle in European elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson is taking a hard line against Russia on the eve of his first diplomatic trip to Moscow, calling the country “incompetent” for allowing Syria to hold on to chemical weapons and accusing Russia of trying to influence elections in Europe using the same methods it employed in the United States.

articles.headline: As Georgia Vote Nears, G.O.P. Asks if Ideological Purity Matters Anymore
articles.snippet: Early voting has begun in a special House election, but in the suburbs north of Atlanta, few seem quite sure what the Republican Party stands for now.
articles.abstract: Early voting has begun in a special House election, but in the suburbs north of Atlanta, few seem quite sure what the Republican Party stands for now.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — When Michael Fitzgerald, a local Republican leader, took a break from packing up the signs after a candidate forum here last week, he appeared momentarily flummoxed about the state of his party under President Trump.

articles.headline: He Buys a Lot of Ads, and He’s Frustrated With Digital
articles.snippet: Marc S. Pritchard, chief brand officer for Procter & Gamble, is leading demands for more data on where ads appear and how views are measured.
articles.abstract: Marc S. Pritchard, chief brand officer for Procter & Gamble, is leading demands for more data on where ads appear and how views are measured.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Marc S. Pritchard, the chief brand officer of Procter & Gamble, has become the face of marketers’ frustrations with digital advertising this year. His message to the industry: Grow up.

articles.headline: How Stephen Colbert Finally Found His Elusive Groove
articles.snippet: Mr. Colbert has done what was unthinkable a year ago: turned “The Late Show” into the most viewed show in late night. And President Trump is not the only reason.
articles.abstract: Mr. Colbert has done what was unthinkable a year ago: turned “The Late Show” into the most viewed show in late night. And President Trump is not the only reason.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the most surprising turnaround stories in recent television history began on one of the most surprising nights in political history.

articles.headline: Can Bill O’Reilly Keep His Scold’s Perch?
articles.snippet: Mr. O’Reilly’s rise was built on railing against the ethical failures of others. But with his own conduct in question, his fans’ trust may not be enough.
articles.abstract: Mr. O’Reilly’s rise was built on railing against the ethical failures of others. But with his own conduct in question, his fans’ trust may not be enough.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2000, cable news’s transformational star — a telegenic scold who knew wrong from right as sure as he knew that a break from “traditional values” would be this nation’s ruination — wrote the following words in his book “The O’Reilly Factor”:

articles.headline: Loans ‘Designed to Fail’: States Say Navient Preyed on Students
articles.snippet: Lawsuits filed by Illinois and Washington against the Sallie Mae spinoff firm say high-risk loans were part of a growth strategy that has left former students buried in debt.
articles.abstract: Lawsuits filed by Illinois and Washington against the Sallie Mae spinoff firm say high-risk loans were part of a growth strategy that has left former students buried in debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ashley Hardin dreamed of being a professional photographer — glamorous shoots, perhaps some exotic travel. So in 2006, she enrolled in the Brooks Institute of Photography and borrowed more than $150,000 to pay for what the school described as a pathway into an industry clamoring for its graduates.
articles.byline: By Stacy Cowley and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Barclays C.E.O. Investigated Over Treatment of Whistle-Blower
articles.snippet: The British authorities are investigating the lender and its chief executive, James E. Staley, after he admitted to trying to learn the identity of the author of an anonymous letter.
articles.abstract: The British authorities are investigating the lender and its chief executive, James E. Staley, after he admitted to trying to learn the identity of the author of an anonymous letter.
articles.lead_paragraph: The British banking giant Barclays is again facing questions about its leadership just as its efforts to turn itself around in the aftermath of the 2012 Libor scandal are starting to take shape.
articles.byline: By Kate Kelly and Chad Bray

articles.headline: Wells Fargo to Claw Back $75 Million From 2 Former Executives
articles.snippet: After an investigation into a sales scandal at the bank, the board pinned most of the blame on its former chief executive and its former head of community banking.
articles.abstract: After an investigation into a sales scandal at the bank, the board pinned most of the blame on its former chief executive and its former head of community banking.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo’s board said on Monday that it would claw back an additional $75 million in compensation from the two executives on whom it pinned most of the blame for the company’s scandal over fraudulent accounts: the bank’s former chief executive, John G. Stumpf, and its former head of community banking, Carrie L. Tolstedt.
articles.byline: By Stacy Cowley and Jennifer A. Kingson
